Iron MaidenÃƒÂ¢??s first live album way back in 1982, but was never released. Showcasing the band at the very start of their 

ÃƒÂ¢??classicÃƒÂ¢?? period, recorded several days before the landmark ÃƒÂ¢??Number of the BeastÃƒÂ¢?? album was released, this excellent 

concert features almost the entire album amidst the best songs from the first two albums, all given a new perspective 

with DickinsonÃƒÂ¢??s operatic vocals. He hasnÃƒÂ¢??t quite established the familiar air siren wail just yet, but thatÃƒÂ¢??s what makes this 

early material all the more interesting, especially when compared to 1985ÃƒÂ¢??s definitive ÃƒÂ¢??Live After Death.ÃƒÂ¢?? This remains the 

final recording to feature drummer Clive Burr. The concert was also recorded on film under the same title, and can now 

be found on ÃƒÂ¢??The History of Iron Maiden part 1: The Early DaysÃƒÂ¢?? DVD, which is also great.
The bandÃƒÂ¢??s early sound is captured perfectly here, as are the hints of the epic heavy metal monster Iron Maiden would 

become, with the lengthy classic ÃƒÂ¢??Hallowed Be Thy NameÃƒÂ¢?? setting the template for pretty much every album-closing track 

forever afterward. Everything is played precisely, but with enough cute errors to authenticate the performance; itÃƒÂ¢??s just a 

shame that the set-list here is almost exactly the same as that on the BBC Archives. Highlights include the cool opener 

ÃƒÂ¢??Murders in the Rue Morgue,ÃƒÂ¢?? the ever-reliable ÃƒÂ¢??Phantom of the OperaÃƒÂ¢?? and the entire performance of the ÃƒÂ¢??Number of the 

BeastÃƒÂ¢?? material, wisely omitting the two weakest songs and even performing the B-side ÃƒÂ¢??Total Eclipse,ÃƒÂ¢?? which was later 

added to re-releases of the album anyway.
Iron Maiden&#039;s 1982 &#039;Beast On The Road&#039; tour has taken on a mythical quality among Metal fans as the tour and the album 

which really put Maiden at the forefront of Rock and Metal worldwide. The historical show from the Hammersmith Odeon 

has been specially mixed and co-produced for the casket by Steve Harris and the band&#039;s long serving sound engineer Doug 

Hall. This double CD clearly illustrates how remarkable and ground breaking the tour was in support of the all time classic 

album, &#039;The Number Of The Beast&#039;. The accompanying inlay booklet is a complete recreation of the &#039;Beast On The Road&#039; 

tour programme and lists all the world tour dates and includes notes from the band written at that time.
